html.p: Proposition. If [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] are square matrices, and [mathjaxinline]AB = I[/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]BA = I[/mathjaxinline], and the two matrices are inverses of each other.
This allows us to add two lines to the Invertible Matrix Theorem:

Invertible Matrix Theorem (updated). Suppose that [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^ n \rightarrow \mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation with (square) standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. Then the following conditions are all equivalent (i.e., either all of them are true, or all of them are false):

li.p: The columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] are linearly independent.
[mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] row reduces to have a pivot in every column (has no free variables).
[mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] row reduces to the identity matrix.
[mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] row reduces to have a pivot in every row.
For every [mathjaxinline]v\in \mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline], the equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = v[/mathjaxinline] is consistent.
The columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline].
There is a matrix [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]AB = I_ n[/mathjaxinline]. ([mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] has a right inverse.)
There is a matrix [mathjaxinline]B[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]BA = I_ n[/mathjaxinline]. ([mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] has a left inverse.)
